summary: This FBI Significant Case Notification from August 15, 2019, details investigative activities following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It covers the SDNY's request to dismiss the case, victim interviews and services, FBI hotline calls, cooperation discussions with co-conspirators, financial analysis, digital evidence processing from searches in the USVI and Manhattan, and complications regarding forfeiture of Epstein's properties.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased subject of the sex trafficking investigation. His death complicates criminal forfeiture proceedings.

persons.name: Judge Berman
persons.context: SDNY judge who ordered a hearing on August 27, 2019, to discuss the prosecution's request to dismiss the case against Epstein and will allow victims to be heard.

persons.name: Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of financial analysis; Western Union had no records on her.

connections.description: Maxwell is referenced as a co-conspirator in the investigation, with a proffer session scheduled with her attorneys.

events.title: SDNY Submits Nolle Pros Request
events.description: The SDNY submitted a request to dismiss the case against Jeffrey Epstein to Judge Berman following Epstein's death.

events.title: Scheduled Hearing on Case Dismissal
events.description: Judge Berman ordered a hearing to discuss the prosecution's request to dismiss the case, citing the public's interest and allowing victims to be heard.

events.title: Victim Interview
events.description: At least one victim was interviewed. Two victims from the indictment were scheduled for interview the next day.

events.title: Proffer Session Scheduled
events.description: A proffer session was scheduled with a co-conspirator (likely Maxwell) and her attorneys in Florida.

events.title: FBI Case Notification
events.description: The FBI issued this significant case notification detailing investigative updates.

locations: USVI (U.S. Virgin Islands, likely referring to Epstein's property)
keyFacts: Following Epstein's death, the SDNY moved to dismiss the criminal case, but Judge Berman scheduled a hearing for August 27, 2019, to allow victims to be heard.
20-30 victims were expected to attend the hearing, with many wanting to speak, and victim services were contacting uncounseled victims, many of whom were 'still in crisis.'
Digital evidence seized included approximately 20 computers from the USVI and multiple devices from Epstein's Manhattan residence, with one iMac containing over 800,000 emails.
The FBI hotline had received 168 total calls, including from a couple who worked for Epstein domestically from 2002-2003.
Epstein's death complicated criminal forfeiture of his properties, as civil forfeiture could prevent victims from seeking compensation from his estate.
